fields.Title of Presentation: There's Something About Albumin: Applying the Roadmap for Causal Inference to Estimate the Effect of Albumin Levels on Pressure Injury Development in Hospital Settings
fields.Description/Abstract: Background:<br>Pressure injuries (PrIs) are a common problem in critical care settings, affecting 3-6% of patients. These<br>injuries are characterized by damage to the skin and underlying soft tissue. While external pressure and<br>shear are the primary causes of PrIs, other factors can also contribute to tissue damage. One such factor<br>is serum albumin, a protein found in blood plasma. Studies have shown that low serum albumin levels<br>can increase the risk of developing PrIs. The multifaceted association between serum albumin and PrI<br>development reflects overall health and nutrition status, necessitating a deeper exploration of albumin's<br>direct impact on PrI risk.<br>Objectives:<br>To accurately assess the effectiveness of a treatment or exposure from observational data, it's essential<br>to carefully consider how the data was collected and factor in any potential confounding variables that<br>could affect the results. We aimed to apply the "roadmap for causal inference" outlined by van der Laan et<br>al. to evaluate the impact of low albumin levels on the incidence of pressure injuries in hospital patients<br>while considering any potential confounding factors that could be present in the population being studied.<br>Methods:<br>Our study employed a plausible directed acyclic graph (DAG) relating albumin to pressure injuries with<br>potential confounders, colliders, and effect modifiers (moderators). We used a nonparametric causal<br>structural framework and employed the roadmap for causal inference and the Targeted Maximum<br>Likelihood Estimation (TMLE) approach to adjust for confounders and estimate the causal effect of low<br>albumin on the development of pressure injuries.<br>Our analysis involved a cohort of patients identified from the MIMIC IV dataset, a de-identified electronic<br>health records dataset from Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center. This dataset captures admissions<br>between 2008 and 2019 for almost 300,000 patients.<br>Results:<br>Our analysis showed that low albumin levels are significantly associated with an increased incidence of<br>pressure injuries in hospitalized patients, even after accounting for various other factors. The crude odds<br>ratio for low albumin was strikingly high at 3.97 (95% confidence interval: 3.54-4.45). We used Targeted<br>Maximum Likelihood Estimation (TMLE) to refine these estimates, and we found that low albumin levels<br>increase the risk of pressure injury by 4.0% (95% confidence interval: 0.03082-0.0496, p < 0.0001). We<br>also discovered a dose-response relationship between albumin levels and pressure injury risk, further<br>supporting the association.<br>Conclusions:<br>Utilizing advanced causal inference techniques, this study provides robust evidence of the contributory<br>role of serum albumin in the development of pressure injuries (PrIs) in critical care. Despite observing a<br>significant variation in PrI risk among patients with liver and kidney diseases, our results did not indicate a<br>significant effect modification, likely due to the increased variability in these sicker patient populations.<br>Nevertheless, the evidence points to low albumin as a potential target for intervention. Our findings lay<br>the groundwork for designing an interventional study with a systematic approach to albumin monitoring<br>and intervention, which could reduce PrI incidence. Moving forward, we aim to delve deeper into the<br>longitudinal aspects of albumin levels and their relationship with PrI, which are essential for<br>understanding the dynamics involved in a potential interventional study.
